🚀 We're Hiring: Python Data Platform Engineer (8+ years of experience and relevant of 5+ years of experience) 🚀📍 Location: Bangalore (Work from Client Site - Minimum 3 days per week) ⏰ Shift Timing: Regular India ShiftWe are looking for an experienced Python Data Platform Engineer. This role will focus on building and optimizing data pipelines, handling complex data transformations, and working with cloud-based data platforms like Snowflake and IBM DB2. If you have a passion for data engineering, working with Python, and optimizing ETL processes, we want to hear from you!Key Requirements:🔹 5+ years of experience in Python & Data Engineering 🔹 Expert in SQL/PLSQL (including DB2) with experience in writing complex queries, stored procedures, triggers, and views 🔹 Hands-on experience with Snowflake, PySpark, and Airflow for data processing, transformation, and orchestration 🔹 Strong understanding of data warehousing concepts (Factless Fact Tables, Bi-Temporal models, etc.) 🔹 Proven experience in performance tuning (DB2 queries, data loads) 🔹 Solid problem-solving and communication skills 🔹 Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related fieldRole Summary:Develop and optimize ETLs, stored procedures, triggers, and views on DB2-based and Snowflake-based data warehousesPerform data profiling and technical analysis to ensure smooth data integrationMonitor performance and optimize data loads and queriesCollaborate with cross-functional teams to implement client-specific business requirementsProvide guidance during QA & UAT phases to resolve issues and ensure data integritySkills You’ll Use:🔧 Python | SQL/PLSQL | Snowflake | PySpark | Airflow | IBM DB2 | Data Warehousing | ETL Development | Performance TuningReady to make an impact? Apply today by sharing your resume to hr@havisoft.in / brunda.m@havisoft.in

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. If a concrete pour is about to start and the slump test fails, what will you do?Answer:Stop the pour and inform the supervisor.Adjust water or admixture as per mix design.Retest until it meets project requirements.Answer:Issue a Non-Conformance Report (NCR).Stop further work until it's rectified.Require a corrective action plan before reinspection.

🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.

STEP NO: 01Quality Control And Quality AssuranceAs a hiring manager, I would ask a variety of technical, situational, and behavioral questions to fully assess your QC Engineering skills and experience. Here are more interview questions with short answers:1. What is the difference between Quality Control (QC) and Quality Assurance (QA)?Answer:QC is inspection-based-it ensures work meets specifications through testing and verification. QA is process-based-it focuses on preventing defects by improving construction procedures.2. What is an Inspection and Test Plan (ITP), and why is it important?Answer:An ITP is a document outlining inspection stages, tests, and acceptance criteria to ensure quality compliance at every step. It helps track progress and maintain standards.3. What are the main tests performed on fresh and hardened concrete?Answer:Fresh Concrete: Slump test, air content test, temperature test.Hardened Concrete: Compressive strength test, flexural strength test, core test.4. How do you verify if concrete meets strength requirements?Answer:I check cylinder/cube test results at 7, 14, and 28 days to confirm they meet design strength as per ACI standards.5. What steps do you follow for soil compaction testing?Answer:1. Conduct Proctor Test to determine optimum moisture content.2. Perform Field Density Test (FDT) using Sand Cone or Nuclear Gauge.3. Ensure compaction meets project specifications (95% or 98% of MDD as required).6. What factors affect the durability of concrete structures?Answer:Water-cement ratio (lower is better).Proper curing to prevent cracks.Use of quality aggregates and admixtures.Correct mix design as per site conditions.7. How do you handle material discrepancies between approved submittals and site deliveries?Answer:I immediately report the issue, hold the material, compare it with approved submittals, and request a replacement if it doesn't match specifications.8. 🚀 If I Were Starting a Startup Again — Here’s What I’d Do Differently7 years building in a tough niche (logistics).Still standing. Still learning.No perfect exits. No hockey stick.But we’re alive — and growing.And if I could talk to my past self…Here’s what I’d say — brutally honestly.---------------------------------------------------🧭 Don’t start with code or a deckStart with pain.Real pain.Then — Excel:✅ What would it cost?✅ Who would pay?✅ How soon would it return?Then: a short brief and client validation.Start with revenue logic. Not features.---------------------------------------------------🛠️ Tech ≠ ProductDev founders build.Buyers decide.At CarGoo (https://cargoo.ua/en) (https://cargoo.io/en), the best improvements were… boring:📄 a better form✍️ a simple comment field⚡ a bit of animationThe “cool stuff” we spent months on? Mostly ignored.Simple, fast, useful beats clever every time.---------------------------------------------------🏗️ No architecture = slow deathIf your product grows and the foundation is weak:💥 You’ll refactor mid-crisis💸 You’ll overpay on infrastructure🐌 You’ll hire more just to move slowerWhat you skip early will come back 10x louder.---------------------------------------------------👥 Hiring isn’t just a checklistTech founders forget soft skills.Non-tech founders don’t even know what to check.And hiring friends? 😬 Risky as hell.Look for ownership. Curiosity. Team fit.---------------------------------------------------🧪 QA is your unsung heroThey catch what breaks — before your users do.They don’t present on demos.But they’re the reason your product still works.No QA = no peace.---------------------------------------------------🎨 UX isn’t art — it’s tractionGood UX means fewer questions, better adoption, and actual love.Your designer can become the soul of your product — or your team’s biggest pain.Invest wisely.---------------------------------------------------🔥 Final thoughtSurround yourself with people who give a damn.Skills can grow.Character — not so much.And yeah — despite all of it, I’d still build.Because there’s nothing like seeing someone use what you created — and smile.💬 If you could send ONE message to your past startup self…What would it be?👇 Slide through — maybe you’ll recognize yourself in here.
